CONFIDENCE: Active Self-Regulation > Strategy Use > Using Context Clues > Inferring Meaning with Context Clues > Vocabulary Expansion

SKILL_NAME: With support, identify words that express feelings in a text
TAXONOMY_PATH: Language Comprehension > Verbal Reasoning > Inferential and Interpretive Reasoning > Interpreting Tone and Mood > Detecting Emotional Undertones > Understanding Emotional Impact
CONFIDENCE: Language Expression > Writing > Writing Process > Revising > Refining Content > Improving Word Choice

SKILL_NAME: Analyze how an author's word choice and use of language impact tone and fit the author's purpose (e.g., how language in an editorial differs from that of a newspaper article)
TAXONOMY_PATH: Language Comprehension > Verbal Reasoning > Analytical Reasoning > Author's Craft and Style > Analyzing Author's Purpose > Analyzing Authorial Intent
CONFIDENCE: Language Comprehension > Literacy Knowledge > Literary Effects > Mood, Tone, and Atmosphere > Analyze Mood, Tone, and Atmosphere > Analyze Mood, Tone, and Atmosphere

SKILL_NAME: Understand and analyze how sensory language creates imagery
TAXONOMY_PATH: Language Comprehension > Literacy Knowledge > Literary Device > Symbolism and Imagery > Imagery > Understanding auditory imagery
CONFIDENCE: Language Comprehension > Literacy Knowledge > Rhetorical Device > Figurative Language > Identify and Interpret Figurative Language > Identify and Interpret Figurative Language

SKILL_NAME: Analyze an author's choice of words and use of language to determine how these choices appeal to the senses, create imagery, and establish mood and tone
TAXONOMY_PATH: Language Comprehension > Literacy Knowledge > Literary Effects > Mood, Tone, and Atmosphere > Analyze Mood, Tone, and Atmosphere > Analyze Mood, Tone, and Atmosphere
CONFIDENCE: Language Comprehension > Verbal Reasoning > Analytical Reasoning > Author's Craft and Style > Analyzing Author's Techniques > Analyzing Literary Device Usage

SKILL_NAME: Understand the impact of literary devices such as allegory, allusions, symbolism, and sound devices on the meaning of a text
TAXONOMY_PATH: Language Comprehension > Literacy Knowledge > Rhetorical Device > Irony and Sound Devices > Analyze Irony and Sound Devices > Analyze Irony and Sound Devices
CONFIDENCE: Language Comprehension > Literacy Knowledge > Literary Device > Symbolism and Imagery > Symbolism > Understanding symbols in texts

SKILL_NAME: Explain the meanings of simple similes, metaphors, and uses of exaggeration (e.g., as bright as the sun, a ton of homework) in grade-appropriate texts
TAXONOMY_PATH: Language Comprehension > Verbal Reasoning > Inferential and Interpretive Reasoning > Differentiating Literal and Figurative Language > Recognizing Figurative Expressions > Recognizing Metaphors and Similes
CONFIDENCE: Language Comprehension > Verbal Reasoning > Analogical and Comparative Reasoning > Analogical Inference and Application > Recognizing Analogies > Understanding Literal vs. Figurative Analogies

SKILL_NAME: Identify the senses to which specific words or descriptions appeal
TAXONOMY_PATH: Language Comprehension > Literacy Knowledge > Literary Device > Symbolism and Imagery > Imagery > Understanding visual imagery
CONFIDENCE: Language Comprehension > Literacy Knowledge > Literary Device > Symbolism and Imagery > Imagery > Understanding tactile imagery

SKILL_NAME: Understand that texts can communicate a feeling or mood
TAXONOMY_PATH: Language Comprehension > Verbal Reasoning > Inferential and Interpretive Reasoning > Interpreting Tone and Mood > Detecting Emotional Undertones > Understanding Emotional Impact
CONFIDENCE: Language Comprehension > Verbal Reasoning > Inferential and Interpretive Reasoning > Interpreting Tone and Mood > Analyzing Mood Setting > Interpreting Atmospheric Elements

SKILL_NAME: Explain the meaning of metaphors in a fourth-grade text
TAXONOMY_PATH: Language Comprehension > Verbal Reasoning > Inferential and Interpretive Reasoning > Differentiating Literal and Figurative Language > Analyzing Symbolic Representations > Evaluating Metaphorical Meanings
CONFIDENCE: Language Comprehension > Literacy Knowledge > Rhetorical Device > Figurative Language > Identify and Interpret Figurative Language > Identify and Interpret Figurative Language

SKILL_NAME: Combine a vowel and a consonant sound to produce a single syllable
TAXONOMY_PATH: Word Recognition > Phonics and Decoding > Decoding Skills > Blending Skills > Phoneme Blending > Blending Individual Phonemes
CONFIDENCE: Word Recognition > Phonics and Decoding > Decoding Skills > Blending Skills > Onset-Rime Blending > Blending Onset and Rime

SKILL_NAME: Blend grade-appropriate words with a greater number of phonemes, including consonant blends and consonant digraphs (e.g., slide, whisper, branch)
TAXONOMY_PATH: Word Recognition > Phonics and Decoding > Phonics Knowledge > Consonant Sounds > Consonant Blends > Decoding Consonant Blends
CONFIDENCE: Word Recognition > Phonics and Decoding > Phonics Knowledge > Consonant Sounds > Consonant Digraphs > Decoding Consonant Digraphs

SKILL_NAME: Decode by sounding and blending, phoneme by phoneme, regular words including words with adjacent consonants (e.g., CVCC words w-e-n-t, d-e-s-k and CCVC words t-r-i-p, s-t-o-p)
TAXONOMY_PATH: Word Recognition > Phonics and Decoding > Phonics Knowledge > Consonant Sounds > Consonant Blends > Decoding Consonant Blends
CONFIDENCE: Word Recognition > Phonics and Decoding > Decoding Skills > Single-syllable Decoding > CVC Patterns > Decoding CVC Words

SKILL_NAME: Create new syllables by orally blending unfamiliar consonants with familar vowels (e.g., blend the phonemes /n/-/a/ to make the first syllable in nada and /j/-/o/ to make the second syllable in rojo)
TAXONOMY_PATH: Word Recognition > Phonological Awareness > Phonemic Awareness > Phoneme Manipulation > Adding Phonemes > Adding Initial Sounds
CONFIDENCE: Word Recognition > Phonics and Decoding > Decoding Skills > Blending Skills > Phoneme Blending > Blending Individual Phonemes

SKILL_NAME: Segment grade-appropriate words with four or five phonemes, including words with digraphs and blends (e.g., identify the sounds /sh/ /i/ /p/ /s/ in ships)

SKILL_NAME: With support, begin to blend onsets and rimes to form familiar single-syllable words (e.g., blend the sounds /p/ /an/ to pronounce pan)

CONFIDENCE: Word Recognition > Phonological Awareness > Syllable Awareness > Syllable Manipulation > Syllable Blending > Combining Syllables into Words

SKILL_NAME: Blend phonemes, including consonant blends, to pronounce two-syllable and three-syllable words (e.g., blend the sounds /blu/ /sa/ to produce blusa; blend /ha/ /bla/ /do/) to produce hablado
TAXONOMY_PATH: Word Recognition > Phonics and Decoding > Phonics Knowledge > Consonant Sounds > Consonant Blends > Decoding Consonant Blends
CONFIDENCE: Word Recognition > Phonological Awareness > Syllable Awareness > Syllable Manipulation > Syllable Blending > Combining Syllables into Words

SKILL_NAME: Identify and pronounce single-syllable words by blending and segmenting consonant blends, long vowel digraphs, and other phonemes (e.g., identify the sounds /th/ /r/ /ee/ in three and blend the sound /th/ /r/ /ee/ to produce three)

CONFIDENCE: Word Recognition > Phonics and Decoding > Phonics Knowledge > Consonant Sounds > Consonant Blends > Decoding Consonant Blends

SKILL_NAME: Participate in teacher-led oral sounding and blending of CVC words (e.g., "Where is the c-a-t?" "This is my p-e-n.")
TAXONOMY_PATH: Word Recognition > Phonics and Decoding > Decoding Skills > Blending Skills > Phoneme Blending > Blending Individual Phonemes
CONFIDENCE: Word Recognition > Phonics and Decoding > Decoding Skills > Single-syllable Decoding > CVC Patterns > Decoding CVC Words

SKILL_NAME: Decode words consisting of two or more syllables that contain taught graphemes (e.g., container, pavement, supermarket)

SKILL_NAME: Decode by blending, phoneme by phoneme, a wider range of three-letter CVC words made from grapheme-phoneme correspondences that have been taught (e.g., l-e-g, r-u-n, p-o-t)

CONFIDENCE: Word Recognition > Phonics and Decoding > Phonics Knowledge > Vowel Sounds > Short Vowels > Decoding Short Vowel Sounds

CONFIDENCE: Word Recognition > Phonics and Decoding > Phonics Knowledge > Consonant Sounds > Consonant Digraphs > Decoding Consonant Digraphs

SKILL_NAME: Blend grade-appropriate words with four or five phonemes, including words with digraphs and blends (e.g., blend the sounds /sh/ /i/ /p/ /s/ to produce ships)
TAXONOMY_PATH: Word Recognition > Phonics and Decoding > Phonics Knowledge > Consonant Digraphs > Decoding Consonant Digraphs
CONFIDENCE: Word Recognition > Phonics and Decoding > Phonics Knowledge > Consonant Sounds > Consonant Blends > Decoding Consonant Blends

TAXONOMY_PATH: Word Recognition > Phonics and Decoding > Phonics Knowledge > Advanced Patterns > Complex Consonants > Decoding Complex Consonant Patterns
CONFIDENCE: Word Recognition > Phonics and Decoding > Decoding Skills > Blending Skills > Phoneme Blending > Blending Individual Phonemes

SKILL_NAME: Decode, by blending phoneme by phoneme, throughout the word, a variety of words containing a common taught grapheme which may be pronounced differently in each word (e.g., the letter y maps to the phoneme /i:/ in the word happy, the phoneme /aı/ in the word sky, the phoneme /j/ in the word yes)

SKILL_NAME: Listen to a wider range of nonfiction, including reference books and textbooks, that is at a level beyond which could be read independently (e.g., books and source materials relating to topics in history)
Read an increasingly wide range of nonfiction, with a wide coverage of topics, historical periods, forms, and authors, including high-quality works (e.g., styles of different journalists)
Become increasingly familiar with a wider range of stories, fairy tales, and traditional tales
Read a broad range of nonfiction, with an increasingly wide coverage of topics, historical periods, forms, and authors, including high-quality works (e.g., reviews and critiques)
With support, identify and discuss basic elements of simple plays (e.g., main characters)
Listen to a wide range of nonfiction that is at a level beyond which could be read independently
Begin to be aware of how aspects of performance and staging help to communicate the playwright's intentions effectively (e.g., by using a modern day setting for a Shakespeare play)
Understand that some stories are about make-believe things and others are about real life
Explain the elements of plot and character as presented through dialogue in scripts that are read, viewed, written, or performed
Analyze how playwrights characterize their protagonists and antagonists through dialogue and staging
Become familiar with common fairy tales and traditional stories (e.g., be able to recount some events in The Three Little Pigs)
Become familiar with listening to a range of information in a range of contexts (e.g., labels, lists)
Continue to read a wide range of informational texts (e.g., short texts on school topics)
Analyze texts from various academic disciplines to determine how those disciplines organize information and treat domain-specific vocabulary
Critique how texts from various academic disciplines organize information and treat content and domain-specific vocabulary

Listen to and comprehend a wide range of grade-appropriate nonfiction and literary text as well as texts that are at a level beyond which could be read independently (e.g., chapter books, poetry, science articles)
Describe characteristics of different informational texts including biographies, history books, science books, and how-to texts
Analyze the characteristics of different poetic forms (e.g., sonnets, lyric poetry, epic poetry, haiku) and describe how the characteristics influence a text
Describe structural characteristics of poetry (e.g., rhyme, meter stanzas, line breaks) and how they contribute to form (e.g., lyrical poetry, free verse)
Make comparisons between literary texts that have been read previously
Distinguish among genres including poetry, plays, fiction (stories, folktales), and nonfiction (social studies, technical)
Recognize that texts that claim to be true may be fictional or greatly distorted (e.g., "Robinson Crusoe," texts "based on a true story")
Identify how authors use characteristics of different genres (e.g., fiction, poetry, nonfiction, drama) to accomplish different purposes
Deepen understanding of oral tribal history through wide exploration of cultural and historical texts and media
With prompting and support, recognize common types of text
Analyze how a speech writer's use of language and literary devices in passages from well-known speeches appeals to the audience

Increase familiarity with a wider range of books, including myths, legends, and traditional stories, modern fiction, fiction from the English literary tradition, and books from other cultures and traditions
Study a greater range of nonnarrative styles and topics (e.g., arguments, debates)
Describe the phenomena explained by origin myths, and continue to broaden knowledge of mythology and traditional literature
Become familiar with some key nonfiction text types (e.g., simple, single-topic information books)
Analyze and gain increasing familiarity with works of fiction by British authors across major literary periods

Analyze characteristics of different genres of informational texts, including literary nonfiction (e.g., Maya Angelou's I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings, speeches such as Abraham Lincoln's Gettysburg Address) as a framework for interpreting different works

Analyze the characteristics of genres of fiction (e.g., historical fiction, mystery, science fiction, fantasy, myth), and different forms of poetry (e.g., sonnet, haiku, free verse) and drama to begin to establish an interpretive framework for understanding different works

Analyze works in light of their genre characteristics such as a play's dramatic conventions (e.g., chorus, monologue, dramatic irony) or a poem's meter, and analyze how and the degree to which generic conventions affect the text's meaning
Become familiar with an increasing range of stories, fairy tales, myths, and legends
Analyze and explain common elements used in epic tales and mythology such as the extended metaphor and the quest, and compare such stories from various cultures
Identify conventions used in a range of familiar stories (e.g., heroic figures, pattern of three events)
Determine how texts from various academic disciplines organize information and treat domain-specific vocabulary
Identify the elements of dialogue and use them when performing informal plays
Analyze the structure, stylistic elements, conventions, and prosody of poems and determine their contributions
Listen to, and join in with, simple stories and poems
Distinguish between fiction and nonfiction
Analyze personal text preferences, recognize influences, and develop appreciation for a wide variety of genres including works from other countries
Analyze the characteristics and devices of different genres of informational texts, and describe how the characteristics influence a text

Read a wide range of fiction, in particular whole books (e.g., Holes, Alice's Adventures in Wonderland), short stories, poems, and plays with a wide coverage of genres, historical periods, forms, and authors, including high-quality works from English literature, both pre-1914 and contemporary, including prose, poetry, and drama)
Analyze the structure, elements, and genre characteristics of drama and describe how these influence a text
Analyze characteristics of epic tales and myths and recognize how and when these stories influence modern literary texts
Identify and name familiar types of literature such as fairy tales, nursery rhymes, stories, and poems
Identify whether a story is realistic fiction or a fantasy

Describe the person, place, idea, or thing depicted by an informational text graphic

Interpret visual and other multimedia elements (e.g., illustrations, real or fictional maps, sound tracks) to confirm details and deepen understanding of a story (e.g., refer to a fictional map to get a sense of the length of a hero's journey)
Integrate visual, quantitative, and written information to develop a coherent explanation of a topic or issue (e.g., read source material to gather information for a research topic)
Analyze the changing role of the media over time
With support, tell what an author and illustrator contribute to a text
Understand the meaning of text in commonly encountered grade-appropriate media (e.g., written, visual, audio, video)

Compare and contrast multiple interpretations of a story, drama, or poem, analyzing and evaluating how each version interprets the source text (e.g., discuss the similarities and differences between El ingenioso hidalgo don Quijote de la Mancha by Cervantes and the movie Un Hombre de la Mancha by Arthur HIller)
Describe elements of a story (e.g., characters, setting, events) based on information provided by both its illustrations and words
Use information from the illustrations and words in an informational text to comprehend its key details
Use information in illustrations to find key details and deepen understanding of the text
Identify persuasive strategies used by media and analyze the possible effects on readers or viewers
Explain, citing textual details, how visually presented information (e.g., illustrations, charts, graphs, timelines, animations) supports a text's central idea or claim

SKILL_NAME: Select literary books in accordance with developing tastes and preferences, taking into account the purpose for reading (e.g., for challenge, interest, or enjoyment)
Choose literary texts drawing on awareness of purpose and context (e.g., select a book to match a mood or situation—a humorous book to share with others)
Adapt reading style depending on the purpose for reading, using knowledge of text organization (e.g., use knowledge of the alphabetic organization of dictionaries to efficiently search for a word)

Use understanding of the features of different literary text types to select books for a range of purposes (e.g., be able to identify and select a book in a specific genre, using knowledge of conventions gleaned from reading the back cover)

Read nonfiction for a range of purposes and, with prompting, adapt reading style based on these purposes (e.g., when reading to find out specific facts, adapting reading approach by using the table of contents or index)
Begin to take into consideration a task set by a teacher when choosing nonfiction texts (e.g., know how to select a useful text if a teacher asks for information on a particular country)
Continue to choose books independently, from a wide range of literature, in order to develop personal interests and preferences
With support, begin to exercise choice in selecting informational texts
Select the most appropriate nonfiction books for different purposes, including for challenge, interest, and information
Read nonfiction texts for a range of purposes, selecting the most effective reading style for the particular purpose
Identify the purpose for reading specific literary texts that have been chosen independently (e.g., reading all the books in a particular series)
Identify the purpose for reading nonfiction texts chosen independently (e.g., reading how-to books to pursue a hobby)
With support, begin to choose nonfiction books, with some consideration of the purpose for reading
Choose from a wide range of nonfiction books for a variety of purposes, including challenging texts that support learning in other subjects
Establish purpose for reading and apply an understanding of that purpose to guide focus while reading a grade-appropriate text
Establish purpose for reading and apply an understanding of that purpose to enhance comprehension while reading a grade-appropriate text (e.g., adapt reading style depending on purpose)
Confidently and independently self-select texts from a large range of informational texts for personal enjoyment, interest, and academic tasks, including that which is intended for adults
Revisit books encountered previously in order to use information from texts for a variety of purposes
Know that there can be different purposes for reading informational texts, including reading to find out more about a topic

Evaluate informational texts, deciding on value, quality, or usefulness (e.g., looking for possible bias and comparing different sources on the same subject)
Use different techniques to aid understanding and to locate information in a text confidently and efficiently (e.g., skimming, scanning, and close reading)
With support, begin to determine usefulness of nonfiction sources in helping the reader find relevant information effectively (e.g., "Is this a good book for finding information about…?")

Begin to evaluate informational texts, deciding on value, quality, or usefulness (e.g., looking for possible bias and comparing different sources on the same subject)
Employ a variety of print and digital search tools and research strategies to locate credible sources of information to support research or other tasks
Use different techniques to aid understanding and to locate information in a text confidently and efficiently (e.g., skimming, scanning, and close reading), selecting the most relevant information
Adhere to ethical guidelines while finding and recording information from a variety of print and digital sources (e.g., citing sources, attributing quotes, paraphrasing)

Use a variety of print and digital search tools and research strategies (e.g., links from trusted sites) to locate credible sources of information

Use knowledge of grade-appropriate Latin and Greek affixes (e.g., post-, over-, under-, ex-, il-, im-, ir-, -ate, -ive, -ship, -ance, -ence, -ant, -ent) and roots (e.g., gram, polis) to predict the meanings of unfamiliar words (e.g., monogram, metropolis)

Accurately read unfamiliar grade-appropriate multisyllabic words in isolation, using knowledge of word morphology (e.g., autograph, construction)

Determine if a word is aguda, grave, or esdrújula based on location of the accent and the final letter

Decode words with common Latin suffixes, such as: -ción in educación or -mente in lentamente, and identify the meanings of the words

Use knowledge and a wide range of affixes and roots (e.g., Greek, Latin, Anglo-Saxon, African, and Arabic sources), cognates (e.g., Indo-European: night [nuit, nacht, nicht, natt, noc], star [etoile, stella, ster, stern, starn, estrella]), and patterns of how words are formed to predict the meanings of unfamiliar words including content-area and technical vocabulary

Decode words with common affixes (e.g., un-, re-, over-, -er, -est) and familiar base words
Use knowledge of grade-appropriate Greek and Latin roots to predict the meanings of unfamiliar or complex words

Decode one- and two-syllable words that use y as a final or medial vowel, distinguishing between the long /i/, long /e/, and short /i/ sounds

Decode words with diphthongs and isolate the spelling patterns used (e.g., read the words brown, broun, and brawn, and understand that brown is the correct spelling)
Identify the letters that most commonly represent long vowel sounds (e.g., a_e, i_e, o_e, u_e)

Decode words by identifying the correctly spelled CV pattern in a word from a spoken sentence (e.g., Read the words me, lo, and va and recognize that va is the correct spelling in the sentence: "Lisa va a llegar tarde.")

Decode single-syllable (CVC) words (e.g., cat, get, mom)
Isolate and distinguish medial long vowel phonemes in spoken words (e.g., from a verbal prompt, identify that drive has a different middle vowel sound than drove)

Use knowledge of multiple pronunciations of vowel team spelling patterns to decode associated words (e.g., read, bread; hear, learn; pie, piece)
Distinguish short vowel sounds from long vowel sounds in order to discriminate between those sounds in single-syllable words (e.g., reading the words egg, we, and key, egg has the short vowel sound)
Orally distinguish the sounds of the vowels in a single syllable that form a diphthong (e.g., auto, lluvia, agua, aire, ciudad)
